thread.title: 24 federal ATF investigators join probe of St. Charles area country club fire
thread.title_full: 24 federal ATF investigators join probe of St. Charles area country club fire

author: Mark Schlinkmann St. Louis Post-Dispatch
title: 24 federal ATF investigators join probe of St. Charles area country club fire
text:
Close Christian Gooden 
The 18th hole remains flooded by water on Friday, Feb. 17, 2017, after a fire destroyed the Bogey Hills Country Club in St. Charles County. Beginning just before midnight Thursday firefighters from Central County Fire and Rescue were dispatched . The club was completely destroyed. Photo by Christian Gooden, 24 federal ATF investigators join probe of St. Charles area country club fire ( … ) Christian Gooden 
The 18th hole remains flooded by water on Friday, Feb. 17, 2017, after a fire destroyed the Bogey Hills Country Club in St. Charles County. Beginning just before midnight Thursday firefighters from Central County Fire and Rescue were dispatched . The club was completely destroyed. Photo by Christian Gooden, cgooden@post-dispatch.co 
ST. CHARLES COUNTY • A 24-person contingent from the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives has joined the investigation of the fire that destroyed the landmark clubhouse at Bogey Hills Country Club on Friday. 
Central County Fire and Rescue, the local fire department involved, said ATF's national response team and special agents from ATF's Kansas City field office were activated Sunday to take part in the probe. 
Also involved are the state fire marshal's office and the St. Charles County Police Department. 
The ATF response team — one of four around the country — can respond within 24 hours to assist local departments. 
Assistant Chief Steve Brown with Central County Fire and Rescue said ATF's assistance was requested because of the size and extent of the fire scene. He said there is no indication at this point that arson was involved. 
He said the federal agency has the capability of bringing in heavy equipment and other resources not readily available to local and state officials. 
No one was hurt in the fire, which broke out shortly before midnight Thursday. Brown said the investigation is expected to take most of this week. Tags
